Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: insult and non-insult. Insult is any lanugage or act that is disrespectful or scornfully abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: your posts shows you are stupid period
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Would you have blamed the Jews for what the Nazis did to them?
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group, although the question phrased might be controversial.

Negative Examples.explanation: LOL is an acronym of laugh out loud and is non-insult.
This comment contains explicit language and is considered insult.

Comment: I can agree with most of what you say, and all of your concern/support of those hurt by abuse.  Yet, as a professional involved in treating sex offenders, the problems of monitoring offenders is a problematic issue for everyone, not just the Church.  Living in a democracy, with its emphasis on individual rights and limitations on claims of criminal activity (of most crimes).  Both parole and probation have limits, and even offenders retain or regain certain common rights both on and off of court supervision.  The more serious of offenders are required to remain on the Offender Registries of their counties and some for life.  Yet an uncomfortable percentage vanish into the regular population  and that includes some priests and religious.  Bishops have no more (and in fact far less) power to monitor all of those offenders of the Church than the Courts do.  These are realities we must live with, and all the more reason why offender-specific treatment is necessary as our best defense.

Comment: Okay, my second major problem with this article. I am not an historian, so I can't be sure, but I'm pretty sure that the "sex for resources" exchange type of marriage never existed. Up until the early 20th century, I am fairly sure that marriage was fundamentally about securing, maintaining, and extending family wealth. Both men and women were jointly providing services, and both were getting sex, but most negotiations were familial anyway. And even later, once married women were hardly the "keepers" of sex - they were subject to the will of their husbands, leading to John Stuart Mill quote on marriage as the invisible tyranny. So anyway, a far cry from this presentation of "good old days" marriage as a negotiation between two people, marriage was a familial economic planning activity involving the subjugation of women.  But women still bought in because it was the only way they could have sex without suffering community censure.

Comment: Your first argument is not consistent with the statement that you are arguing against. Omitting re-arrests for non-sex crimes has no bearing on the reported re-arrests for sex crimes.

And your second argument is speculation. There is no evidence that a 100% reporting rate of sexual assault incidents would yield any significant differences in the sexual re-offense rate of former offenders. However, whether the re-offense rate is low, high, or unknown, the evidence is clear on what matters here: the current system, which relies heavily on public notification and practices of exclusion, does not create a safer society nor protect potential victims, especially children, from assault. Virtually all child sexual assault is committed by those who are not on the registry but rather a part of the victims' lives and trusted circle of family and acquaintances.

Comment: I would agree with you if the couple was merely asking to buy a cake.  They were not in fact doing so.  They wanted the baker to decorate a cake in a manner that specifically celebrated their gay wedding, something he can’t, in (his) good conscience, do, and which would definitely be an indication of tacit approval.  That tacit approval is specifically why the baker can’t in good conscience make wedding cakes for gay weddings.  You don’t get to determine whether or not such approval exists; that is entirely up to the baker to decide.  And the baker did not say he wouldn’t bake cakes for gays, he said: “Sorry guys, I don’t make cakes for same-sex weddings.”  The distinction is very important, and I suspect will eventually be the determining factor in the case.
What if we add an opposite law?  Can /should the government require the gay community to purchase cakes from that baker despite their own consciences?

With tens of thousands of Korean and Chinese women reportedly being forced to be sex slaves, you would think that at least one of them would have come forward to make the allegation immediately after the war, yet none did. I am a bit skeptical about claims made 47 years after they allegedly occurred.

Comment: If you're going to drill into the matter, please do so accurately. TWU fully acknowledges that non-heterosexual marriages are the law of the land. Nevertheless, it is true that a legally-married LBGTQ couple would have to voluntarily agree not engage in sexual intimacy while one or the other attends TWU. Comment: MC, First, this site purports to use some mix of "NEA, job survey and private data" to come up with their numbers. In their own words, it's "tricky business". Second, the numbers aren't actual salaries, but are a "comfort index" which tries to give a weighted metric vis a vis cost of living(which can vary a lot within states). Hardly "hard data" to make a policy decision off of, but perhaps useful for rookie teachers looking for work, maybe.  Just having starting and average salaries doesn't tell you the whole story. Averages can be skewed by very  high/low earners, a more useful number is median salary. And again, it doesn't address the total compensation issue, or any other factors that are involved that make one state's situation different from anothers. Still waiting for that comprehensive study to be dug up. I think I'll be waiting a while.

Comment: "Evidence?" for a practice of a millennium? First of all, the Vatican was not strict with US Eastern Rite Churches. US Eastern Catholics early on voluntarily abandoned both ecclesiastical divorce and married clergy to quell controversy with US Latin Catholics. But the traditional practices continued in the old world. The council of Trent's statement about divorce and remarriage, in the 16th century, was adjusted to not condemn the Eastern practice. Also, Henry VIII never had a divorce, he only had annulments, and the Church of England's position on divorce and remarriage was for some time the same as the Latin Church. The ecclesiastical divorce and remarriage that was once the traditional practice of Eastern Catholics is the same as that now practiced by the Orthodox. If you really believe they're equivalent to annulments, you should have no problem if Rome adopts the Orthodox practice.

Comment: Pepe LePew,
The State of Alaska assumed the Child Protection Services for Alaska Natives because Alaska was put under PL280, with five other states. Tribes had no say in the matter.

What PL280 is : "Public Law 280 is a federal statute enacted by Congress in 1953. It enabled states to assume criminal, as well as civil, jurisdiction in matters involving Indians as litigants on reservation land. Previous to the enactment of Public Law 280, these matters were dealt with in either tribal and/or federal court."

States : "Enumerated in Public Law 280 were six states which were obligated to assume jurisdiction from the outset of the law: Alaska, California, Minnesota, Nebraska, Oregon, and Wisconsin. States that have assumed at least some jurisdiction since the enactment of Public Law 280 include: Nevada, South Dakota, Washington, Florida, Idaho, Montana, North Dakota, Arizona, Iowa, and Utah." (Note: Metlakatla in Alaska retained rights)

*States can opt out of PL280.
*ICWA 1978 All states

Comment: Single-payer healthcare in California? The annual cost was: $400 billion. Of that, $200 billion would come from existing federal, state and local funding for healthcare. The plan of universal healthcare activists is to convince President Trump and the Republican-controlled Congress to transfer all the Medi-Cal billions to help leftist California finance a single-payer system, something they’d fear and deride as socialized medicine. The committee analysis assumed a 15% payroll tax on income. This in a state that already suffers from the highest income tax rates in the nation. But if all this happened, there’d still be between $50 billion and $100 billion in new money needed to fund a single-payer healthcare system. There’d be no premiums, co-pays or deductibles — and therefore no self controls. So who knows how steep new medical costs would climb?

By George SkeltonContact Reporter
Capitol Journal California

Comment: National Socialist Party v. Skokie (1977)

National Socialist Party of America was declined a permit to speak in Chicago, the organizers turned to the small, ethnically Jewish town of Skokie—where 1/6th of the Jewish population was made up of families that had survived the Holocaust. County authorities attempted to block the Nazi march, but their efforts were overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court in a terse ruling.

R.A.V. v. City of St. Paul (1992)

After a teenager burned a makeshift cross on the lawn of an African-American couple, the St. Paul Bias Motivated Crime Ordinance—which prohibited symbols that "[arouse] anger, alarm or resentment in others on the basis of race, color, creed, religion or gender"—came into effect. In a unanimous ruling written by Justice Antonin Scalia, the Court held that the ordinance was excessively broad.

Comment: It isn't the truth that might be wrong, it is asking the question. I used humor to demonstrate the rudeness and callowness of asking such a question. Assuming you are for real, would you ask that question of any stranger, or even of an acquaintance? If so, you are rude. There are a lot of things other people would think they have no reason to tell you, because those things are none of your business; for instance, "How much money do you make?" "Are those your breasts or are they implants?" Get it? No reasonable person would ask those things except possibly, of someone they knew well; and even then they might expect to be told off.

We have a right to privacy - the Supreme Court has said so. Beyond that, our social norms say that minding one's own business is a basic respect that everyone expects to receive from others.

Comment: The lower dam was apparently plugged by rafting up logs then submerging them by piling rock on them, to form a latticework plug, of sorts, so why not just dredge them out and let the river flow under the dam, then install a gate to store water for times of drought? The upper dam could have been similarly drilled under to allowed the lakes to refill in flood season, protecting downstream property and then used as a reservoir in Summer. We spent millions of scarce tax dollars for the aesthetics of a "wild" canyon for a few tourists. Once the lakes were drained the dams could collapse in an earthquake with no real harm done, but would likely stand if a seismic sensor automatically opened the drains if things started rocking. Now we have to spend millions more each year repairing flood damage and building new reservoirs, which will likely have their own hazards, and the animals and birds that had come to rely on those lakes for habitat had to move on or die. Idiots R Us. Your tax $ @ jerk.

Comment: And then there is hearsay in court, courtesy of FindLaw » Learn About The Law » Criminal Law » Criminal Procedure » "Hearsay" Evidence:
---
"The rule against hearsay is deceptively simple and full of exceptions. Hearsay is an out of court statement, made in court, to prove the truth of the matter asserted. In other words, hearsay is evidence of a statement that was made other than by a witness while testifying at the hearing in question and that is offered to prove the truth of the matter stated. For example, Witness A in a murder trial claimed on the stand: "Witness B (the "declarant") told me that the defendant killed the victim." The definition of hearsay is not too difficult to understand. But the matter can become very confusing when one considers all of the many exceptions to the general rule against hearsay..."

Comment: Hi Rage,
The selection you shared doesn't contradict what I've said. To start, my statement was about sex offenders generally, not just child molesters. The numbers you're providing are regarding child molesters in particular. 
Further, if you look at the line directly before the line you've cited, it reads: "The researchers reported that 5.1 percent of the child molesters in the study were rearrested for a new sex crime within 3 years of their release..." meaning that 95% of child molesters were not re-arrested for a new sex crime. 
The numbers you have cited have to do with comparing subsets of child molesters: those with more than one prior arrest versus those with only one type of prior arrest. 
Lastly, regarding the bit that starts with "As might be expected...", what they're saying here is that child molesters were more likely than other types of sex offenders to commit a sex crime against a child after release, which is different than re-offense rates.
Does that clear things up?

Comment: Loving your neighbor as your yourself does not imply that you ought not kill your neighbor to prevent them from deliberately and intentionally acting in a manner that grievously violates your basic rights and dignity.

Further, Christian love, of the type regarded in the commandment, "Thou shalt love...", cannot be seen as emotive. It is a position in which we place ourselves with regard to others, taking into consideration their perspective. Christian love can easily be understood as equality of respect (in fact, this is what the vast majority of Christian theologians and philosophers have claimed for the past 2,000 years).

But, there is nothing inherently disrespectful in killing the person who, without justification, attempts to kill me, rape me, torture me, etc. If you believe that God is love and that he does condemn some souls to either hell or incredibly tortorous stints in pergatory, then you must believe that you can love someone while imposing physical pain and even death.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Comment: I agree that the U.S. role in the world isn't about friendship and never has been. It's purely about self-interest, and it's in not in our interests to extricate ourselves from relationships and alliances in which we have major influence. Yes, we pay more than our fair share to maintain these relationships, but that's what happens when you're the big dog.

The nations of the world are not a "community" in any serious sense. But, like it or not, they are more interdependent today than ever before in human history. That interdependence is only going to increase, with or without the U.S., and it would be the height of folly for us to surrender our influence as that happens.

Comment: UC: Across our country there are newspapers whose editorial policy may be liberal and others whose may be conservative.  It's likely that, as you mention with syndicated columnists, that the RG is more liberal than conservative.  Remember, the paper is privately owned and the staff, including editorial staff, is hired by the publisher/owner.  As I've often mentioned, when visiting relatives in Tulsa, Oklahoma, I read the Tulsa World which is far more conservative than the RG is liberal.....but, hey, they are their papers and their editorial policy is their business.

On the other hand, if papers "slant" news stories and, in effect, mix "opinion" into news articles, that's very different.  If you catch the RG doing that, by all means you should complain....both on this site and directly to the publisher.  IMO, that's not an issue with the RG.  If you think it is, please cite examples.  Regards and a Happy New Year,  Gary Crum

The key issue is whether one regards Tradition as virtually unchanged, or constantly changing. Once one grasps the constancy of theological development in the past, the Tradition becomes a great friend, for it is the unassailable warrant for the changes we desperately need today. 

Incidentally, in my view, it is not just historical depth in time but also historical breadth in geography (the Byzantine, Syrian, Egyptian Traditions) of the first millennium that warrant change. Since the Great Church (as come call it) of the first millennium was largely united, all the theologies of  all those culturally diverse Churches are fully valid today as markers in the past of what could be in the future. You may recall for example, that before the two recent synods, the wide range of possible solutions for remarried Catholics included the practice of the Byzantine Church. But for the numerical preponderance of JP2 priests, I think Francis would have taken us there.

Comment: Because human beings, like other primates, are hard-wired to expect a sexual division of labour.  Yes, in hunter-gatherer societies it's the males who went after the big game.  But even in those societies there are many roles that are sex-specific but have nothing to do with size or physical attributes.  The division of sex roles is often quite arbitrary.  With a few obvious exceptions, such as the hunting example you mentioned, it doesn’t really matter what role is assigned to which sex.  The important thing is that they're a binary opposition.  Think de Saussure, think Levi-Strauss.

I’d argue that the perverse attempt to steamroll over human nature is the cause of much mental illness today, particularly gender dysphoria and disorders of sexual attraction.

Consequently, police shoot to kill to protect themselves at the first, often misinterpreted, sign of threat.  Once in a while aggressive approach is necessary.  Usually, the matter in question is not so important and it would be better to let the perp go rather than to kill him.   With this change in attitude, police need not recklessly enter into harm's way and shoot to kill without observation, evaluation, and reflection.

Comment: Also, the issue of "feeding an ever-growing world population" starts with managing the global birth rate.  Our earth has a do-not-exceed carrying capacity, and the boom-to-bust overpopulation / dieoff cycle is well recognized by biologists.  We may be dangerously close to that scenario.  

Fish is high-quality protein, but fish farming on the scale needed to feed a hungry world should be driven by the ecology of the process.  Just like land agriculture, the need is to grow the most food, sustainably, with the least burden to the planet.  That means fish that are capable of turning food into fish flesh most efficiently, raised in operations that consume the least resources and generate the least pollution.

If butterfish farming can meet those criteria, fine.  If not, it shouldn't be touted as the potential solution to world hunger -- and should be conducted on an appropriate scale.

Comment: If you're healthy, remain calm, and have experience with cold water, it's highly unlikely you'll die of shock. Panicking because you think you're going to die just might kill you. It's best to wear a wool hat and a wetsuit, drysuit, long underwear, or rain gear, but no cotton.  If you have suitable clothing and a PFD, you can survive for several hours, but your judgment and coordination will be lousy after about fifteen minutes. A PFD helps to reduce heat loss because you don't need use energy treading water.  The most dangerous part is when you get out of the water and it starts evaporating off you body. Wind makes it worse. It's surprising how much a hat helps. Also eating and keeping hydrated. It's a good idea to have at least two boats along with throw lines, safety equipment, and practice. Have a plan for what to do in the event of a capsize.

Genetically she's correct, but practically she's not.  Read a really good book about two decades ago where the author tried to explain why there are cultural differences between our races.  He basically boiled it down to location.  Races that lived in the more moderate or tropical climates had many means of accessing food and the challenges by the weather for shelter was minimal.  The necessity for technology was minimized.  Cultures in climates farther away from the equator had to not only fight for resource but also develop technologies to advance in the harsher conditions. Comment: When I was learning how to handled firearms, I was always taught that there is no such thing as a "gun accident". There can only be carelessness or negligent gun handling and they are not the same as an "accident". There is no way anyone can say "I didn't know that the gun was loaded" and called it an accident. One of the first things I was taught was that you make sure if the gun is loaded....or not. That by itself, really is common sense and known to nearly everyone, even non-gun owners!!  If you do not check, then that make you either careless or utterly negligent person. 

But if you are out there hunting and without knowledge, you get shagged and your trigger "accidently" get pull and you wounded someone or killed some luckless person, that may be an accident. Comment: Our rights are integral to being a Canadian. They are not a gift from the government, they supersede government. They are the bedrock on which all the rest of the Constitution of Canada stands. With our Charter rights delineated, the Canadian people then grant our government the right to govern; and for its side of the bargain the government assures us that it will not trespass on our Charter rights.

So when a politician blithely claims that she will invoke the NWC and violate our rights, she is in effect hammering at the foundation of our country. It's not just tampering with a few lines of legislation. It's toying with the fundamental agreement between the people and the State. One would hope that those politicians had more respect for our democracy.

There is only one justifiable reason to invoke the NWC: when the lawful interpretation of the Charter nevertheless violates the fundamental rights of Canadians in a profound and extensive way. Those situations are very rare.

So, glance at people but don't glare - in every species of animal, including human, glaring is a sign of aggression. Read AT's sequence of events - the drunk glared at AT, but after that AT escalated first, at every step of the way. What would have happened if AT had glanced at the man, seen that he was a sitting drunk, and just walked on? Nothing! That's so easy! Maybe the drunk would have cursed or something, so what? AT might have taken out his cell phone and called the police. Instead, he escalated, endangering both himself and the drunk guy. Let sleeping dogs lie. Don't be a self-appointed vigilante. There's no way anyone can get rid of all the jerks in the world.

Comment: Okay, I didn't read the entire essay.  I stopped about half way through when it became clear to me that her father raised her as a "black person" rather than as a "person", and imbued in her a racial tension that prevents her from "fitting in".

Over the years, I have worked with people of many ethnic origins, all having the quality that they didn't see themselves as of any particular ethnicity.  From the inside looking out, I can't see myself, just as they couldn't see themselves.  It was this attitude that made us compatible co-workers. Rufinus quotes one of the Desert Fathers he interviewed, giving an excellent Platonic answer to a question about the origin of the virtues: "The mother of all the virtues is diákrisis," that word meaning discernment, discretion, and discrimination, all at once.

I don't have to presume anything, because it's already happened and the university provided their rationale for shutting it down via a press release. 

An example of begging the question would be: "We know sexual assault on campus is a huge issue because of campus rape culture."  The presumption that campus rape culture exists, means something to the reader, and implies some evidence about incidence rates, is central to the argument. It's just the same argument, restated twice in two different forms as 'evidence'.

Comment: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof;

Establishment Clause - This clause prohibits a joining between government and religion, such as no official state religion, no preference by government of one faith over another or religion generally, no taxes to support religion, and no government support for religious worship or practice.

Free Exercise Clause – This clause provides each individual with the right to freely practice the religion of his or her choosing. It ensures the autonomy houses of worship and other religious institutions from government in matters of internal governance and religious law. It prohibits government from enacting laws that specifically target religion.

Basically, keep your govt out of my religion and keep your religion out of my govt.   Beware that Islam does not allow for this.
